Results.name: Greenwich Hotel
Results.description: Robert DeNiro and partners spared nothing in their luxurious eight-story hotel, which opened in 2008.

Results.name: Crosby Street Hotel
Results.description: Opened in SoHo in 2009, this Kit Kemp–designed 11-story brownstone has floor-to-ceiling windows throughout and is environmentally certified as an LEED Gold property.

Results.name: The NoMad Hotel
Results.description: That stray capital M is a nod to the neighborhood; fairly recently a no-man’s-land, the district North of Madison Park is a Manhattan renewal success story in the making.

Results.name: The Mark
Results.description: This hotel really lives up to its claims of sophistication and elegance.

Results.name: Andaz Wall Street
Results.description: This “very cool” 42-story property, which opened on Wall Street in 2010, has a sculptural steel-and-stone staircase that links the public areas.

Results.name: The Plaza Hotel
Results.description: The exceptional spa and 24-hour butler service make it worth the splurge.

Results.name: Mandarin Oriental, New York
Results.description: “Top of the line” rave supporters of this “modern yet elegant” Midtown luxury destination, where you'll need “money to burn.”

Results.name: The Carlyle
Results.description: This is the old-world, old-money face of Manhattan, the Upper East Side, where the wealthy... pass their time, leaving downtown to the trend-chasers and aspirants.

Results.name: The Surrey
Results.description: The interior is a showcase for contemporary design; standard “salons” (rooms) have been beautifully furnished with ornate carpets, hand-crafted wardrobes and funky, modern desks.

Results.name: The London NYC
Results.description: Stylish and sophisticated, the London NYC merges the flair of both its namesake cities, with the added bonus of Gordon Ramsay's first stateside restaurant.

Results.name: Gramercy Park Hotel
Results.description: Designed by Ian Schrager, the man behind Miami Beach's Delano and West Hollywood's Mondrian, the Gramercy Park Hotel is as bold --- if not, at times, bolder --- than the city it calls home.

Results.name: The James New York
Results.description: Opened in September, 2010, this Modernist addition to SoHo has a permanent art collection and 114 rooms with natural linen bedding and reclaimed-wood floors.

Results.name: Ace Hotel NYC
Results.description: Hipster hang out with haute gastropub, buzzy seafood joint, packed lobby bar and stylish vintage vibe

Results.name: The Bowery Hotel
Results.description: Strategically positioned mirrors mask the smallness of some rooms, and large marble baths with brass fixtures make up for the lack of space.

Results.name: The Chatwal, New York
Results.description: A restored art deco jewel in the heart of the Theater District, the Chatwal is as atmospheric as it is historic.

Results.name: Andaz 5th Avenue
Results.description: Youthful, chic Andaz ditches stuffy reception desks for hip, mobile staff who check you in on iPads in the art-laced lobby.

Results.name: The Peninsula New York
Results.description: “For very special occasions”, this “luxurious” Midtowner in a “landmark” 1905 building makes guests “feel like royalty”, setting the “gold standard” from “first-class” staffers.

Results.name: Hotel on Rivington
Results.description: The “unique” rooms have enviable views over the East River and downtown’s sprawl, along with hanging flat-screen TVs.

Results.name: Gansevoort Meatpacking NYC
Results.description: This 187-room Meatpacking District hotel is more than its lauded rooftop pool.

Results.name: The Ritz-Carlton Central Park
Results.description: The sight (and, it must be said, smell) of carriage horses greets you as you enter this 33-story, limestone-fronted building on the southern edge of Central Park.

Results.name: Daniel
Results.description: Clearly this is a world-class dining establishment, as evidenced by a bunch of Michelin stars and Barack Obama visits.

Results.name: Le Bernardin
Results.description: It’s hard to keep food in your mouth when your jaw keeps dropping in awe. And awestruck you’ll be at chef Eric Ripert’s skilled transformation of everything that swims into his pristine dishes.

Results.name: Per Se
Results.description: A tasting menu for two at superchef Thomas Keller's plushly impersonal 16-table dining room overlooking Columbus Circle will last three hours and set you back a cool 500 clams.

Results.name: Eleven Madison Park
Results.description: Where the elite meet to greet.

Results.name: Marea
Results.description: Carefully sourced, meticulously prepared fish and seafood take center stage at this well-pedigreed restaurant.

Results.name: The Spotted Pig
Results.description: Like the gastropubs of London, which have taken classic fare and settings and made them cool, she serves items like crispy pigs’ ear salad and squid with roasted fennel to great acclaim.

Results.name: Momofuku Noodle Bar
Results.description: Anything that gives more people easier access to David Chang’s steamed buns of pork belly, hoisin, scallion and cucumber is a humanitarian advance.

Results.name: The Breslin
Results.description: Meet. Wait. Meat. Lamb burgers is a culinary gem.

Results.name: Jean Georges
Results.description: The fireworks are on the plate, where chef-owner Jean-Georges Vongerichten explores tastes and textures, with a few Asian ingredients thrown in for good measure.

Results.name: The Dutch
Results.description: An instant hit when it opened, The Dutch continues to be upbeat, boisterous, and hotter than ever.

Results.name: Babbo
Results.description: Chef Mario Batali’s flagship restaurant is housed in this beautiful Village duplex – paradise for high-quality pasta and offal lovers alike.

Results.name: Masa
Results.description: Despite its prosaic locale in the Time Warner Center, this is one of NY's most impressive restaurants.

Results.name: Del Posto
Results.description: GREAT restaurants may start out that way. But an extraordinary restaurant generally develops only over time, the product of prolonged artistic risk and managerial attention.

Results.name: Momofuku Ssam Bar
Results.description: Like a Botox-addled phoenix, David Chang’s Momofuku Ssäm Bar has undergone more nips and tucks than Jocelyn Wildenstein, but it has come away better for it each time.

Results.name: Momofuku Ko
Results.description: The World's 50 Best Restaurants

Results.name: Pok Pok NY
Results.description: Pok Pok NY, in Red Hook, Brooklyn, is a family-friendly Thai restaurant with good food and lousy service.

Results.name: Peter Luger Steak House
Results.description: Peter Luger lets the steaks speak for themselves, and it works: the chain, including this tavern-like Williamsburg location, is consistently voted the best steakhouse in NYC.

Results.name: Locanda Verde
Results.description: The food is so flat-out seductive—and reasonably priced—you understand quickly why so many diners are clamoring.

Results.name: aldea
Results.description: Name is Portuguese for “village” but space is as urbane-modern as they come. Azure front wall references the sea, hanging rod chandelier in back nods to air.

Results.name: Brushstroke
Results.description: There are three ways to dine at Brushstroke, all of them pretty, well, splendid.

Results.name: Central Park
Results.description: Rambling yet contained, nature-filled yet man-made, this 843-acre oasis provides a welcome respite from the concrete jungle for locals and tourists alike.

Results.name: Frick Collection
Results.description: This spectacular art collection sits in a mansion built by prickly steel magnate Henry Clay Frick, one of the many such residences that made up Millionaires’ Row.

Results.name: Empire State Building
Results.description: The Empire State Building is an art deco monument to progress, a symbol for New York City, and a star in some great romantic scenes, on- and off-screen.

Results.name: Brooklyn Bridge
Results.description: Stroll across this National Historic Landmark for harbor vistas and up-close looks at what was...

Results.name: Tenement Museum
Results.description: Offers a glimpse of what life in the turn-of-the-20th-century Lower East Side was like for those who lived there.

Results.name: The Metropolitan Museum of Art
Results.description: You could spend weeks here admiring the collections.

Results.name: Museum of Modern Art
Results.description: The masterpieces in the permanent collection are too numerous to mention.

Results.name: Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum
Results.description: A sculpture in its own right, architect Frank Lloyd Wright’s building almost overshadows the collection of 20th century art it houses.

Results.name: American Museum of Natural History
Results.description: No matter which wing you wander through or where your curiosities lie (dinosaurs, gems or something else entirely), it’s hard to explore this Upper West Side fixture without being awestruck.

Results.name: Grand Central Terminal
Results.description: The greatest visual impact comes when you enter the vast majestic main concourse.

Results.name: High Line
Results.description: Built on an abandoned railway track, the space is ingenious in its use of reclaimed industrial detritus, a necessity in footage-starved Manhattan.

Results.name: Brooklyn Museum
Results.description: Housed in a monumental Beaux-Arts building, this is New York's second-largest art museum besides...

Results.name: New York Botanical Garden
Results.description: Flowers galore in the heart of da Bronx.

Results.name: Ellis Island
Results.description: Ellis Island is situated about halfway between lower Manhattan and the Statue of Liberty in New York Harbor.

Results.name: The Cloisters
Results.description: The Cloisters is a series of medieval passageways reconstructed from French monasteries and incorporated within a modern museum.

Results.name: New-York Historical Society
Results.description: As the antiquated hyphenated name implies, the Historical Society is the city’s oldest museum, founded in 1804 to preserve the city’s historical and cultural artifacts.

Results.name: United Nations Headquarters
Results.description: An extraterritorial community within New York, the U.N. is abuzz with diplomats from all corners of the world, some in the native dress of their home countries.

Results.name: Washington Square Park
Results.description: NYU students, street musicians, skateboarders, jugglers, chess players, and those just watching the grand opera of it all generate a maelstrom of activity.

Results.name: Staten Island Ferry
Results.description: Staten Islanders know these hulking, dirty-orange ferryboats as commuter vehicles, while Manhattanites like to think of them as their secret, romantic vessels for a spring-day escape.

Results.name: Rubin Museum of Art
Results.description: This sleek and serene museum spread over six floors is the largest in the Western Hemisphere dedicated to the art of the Himalayas.
